A dangerous heat wave is spreading across the southern and central United States, with temperatures up to 20 degrees above normal and the heat index reaching dangerously high levels. Major cities such as Dallas, San Antonio, New Orleans, and Nashville are expected to have a heat index of 110 to 120 degrees over the next few days. This oppressive heat is causing difficulty for many, from families trying to spend time outside to businesses that have to work in the heat. Wildlife is also being affected, with Wild at Heart Rescue coming to the aid of overheated animals. Northern California is also expected to experience higher temperatures, with Sacramento and the San Joaquin Valley under excessive heat warnings. This heat wave is expected to last through the weekend, with no nighttime relief.

  1. A heat wave has spread across the southern and central United States, with temperatures up to 20 degrees above normal.
  2. Major cities where the heat index could reach between 110 to 120 degrees include Dallas, San Antonio, New Orleans and Nashville.
  3. The heat index is a measure of how heat and humidity make the air feel, and health experts consider a heat index of over 103 degrees dangerous.
  4. Nighttime temperatures will offer little respite, staying unseasonably high even while the sun is down.
  5. Low humidity and gusty winds will increase fire danger across much of the Southwest.

"The heat wave is like a giant wave of fire sweeping across the US, scorching cities with temperatures up to 20 degrees higher than normal and a dangerous heat index of over 103 degrees. Even at night, the heat won't let up, and low humidity and gusty winds will only add"
